text: Well, so just for some context, the draft of that white paper was well beyond 100 pages. That was trimmed, trimmed, trimmed down. But it is a very technical, very dense paper, because it's answering a lot of questions in and around how you address a lot of these problems in gaming on chain. And so it's a simple solution to a lot of nuanced and complex problems. And one of the more difficult is like, okay, so we, as Pixel Vault, wanted to put out our game. Most games in web three are web two based games, leveraging web three assets where the entire game state, the game itself, is hosted on a server. And the only thing existing on chain is the assets that may or may not be being used as like just token gates. Hardly ever are they used actually in the game. There's another level of that where the assets themselves are represented in the game, which is great, but most of the activity is done off chain. Then there's full on chain gaming, where everything you do is on chain. Most often this is happening on Solana or some l two s just because of TPS transaction cost. All of those things stack up very quickly. We are trying to address a number of those factors, incorporating like skill based matchmaking on chain, on chain, skill rating on chain wager systems, and being able to level games of skill on top of that. Incorporating the NFTs to drive practical application and utility to these on chain assets, ideally driving value back to those token holders. And so, this is very different than the traditional connotation of like play to earn, where like, the closest analogy I seem to have found is a lot of people comparing it to the magic ecosystem. But a lot of the magic ecosystem is kind of show up, put in your punch card, do your on chain check in for the day, and roll the dice on the tokens that you're going to earn with the intention of offloading them. This is not those similar kind of grind mechanics. There are incentives built into driving people to be compelled to play. But it's that on chain transfer of value, and it actually being deterministic on your this game of skill to then participate in, like using the arcade analogy, you like put the quarter in, you play a game of skill based on that game of skill, you get tickets out, you take those tickets to like, the prize cage and spend it on in game rewards, which in this case happen to be nfts. And through that, there's like all of these on chain mechanisms where there's collateral, everything in the ecosystem is collateralized. So when you're spending those tickets, most of that value is actually going in as collateral within those nfts that can then be either converted, transformed, or burned to claim the underlying collateral or transform them into other goodies within other ecosystems. It's really focusing on this idea of composability rather than interoperability. Instead of using one asset across many places, you can use many, like the collateral within one asset to port it into many different ecosystems. And it's building a bigger arcade with a lot more games in it, rather than a bunch of stores right next to each other that don't use the same currency with only one game in them.
